awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research:   Individual-level Knowledge of an Incoming Phonemic Contrast
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this dissertation research is to contribute to our understanding of how speakers deal with sound change in progress. It will combine socio- and psycholinguistic approaches in order to compare individuals' production and perception of a sound that is new in the language variety that they speak. One of the major ways that languages change through time is by the loss and gain of sound categories (phonemes). A sound is a phoneme category in a language if changing the sound changes meaning. For example, TH is a phoneme in English, and changing TH to S changes the word THINK to SINK. A speaker whose language does not have a particular sound will perform worse on tasks that ask him to recognize or use that sound than a speaker whose language does have it. Individuals learning a new language typically struggle to produce unfamiliar sounds, or to tell two sounds apart. But what about a speaker who is in the middle of this kind of language change? How will this speaker perform with the new sound, and what can we say about the number of phonemes in their sound system? By zooming in on a sound change happening right now in the city of Seville, Spain, this project will challenge assumptions about what it means to have a sound category. It will add to knowledge about phoneme mergers, joining a new line of research expanding beyond Germanic vowels. In conducting the project, the researcher will train a local student in linguistic research skills. Finally, the focus of this study on a low-prestige variety of continental Spanish will support the idea that socio- and psycholinguistic studies of nonstandard varieties can contribute to our scientific understanding of human language.

S and TH are different sound categories in most of Spain. The standard ("correct") way to speak Spanish in Spain uses both sounds as English does, so that replacing S with TH can change e.g., casa 'house' to caza 'hunt'. The research will be conducted in the city of Seville, where speakers are now beginning to use both S and TH, rather than just S (a pattern known as "seseo"). Some speakers go back and forth between using only S and using both sounds. This project examines these speakers' language systems by looking both at how they normally speak (how much they use TH, and when), and how well they perform on tasks with this sound. Sociolinguistic interviews will be conducted with a sample of young adult speakers. The behavior observed will be compared to data collected in a battery of psycholinguistic experiments. From these the researcher will evaluate the speakers' low and high-level perception of the sounds S and TH, and mental representations of standard and nonstandard forms containing these sounds. The results of the sociolinguistic and psycholinguistic studies will be combined to form a holistic picture of the individual phonological systems resulting from contact between merged and unmerged varieties.

por.por_cntn:
When a language uses a sound to distinguish words from each other, linguists say the the sound is a phoneme in that language. But what does it mean for an individual speaker to have, or not have, a phoneme? Usually, a speaker of a language in which a particular sound is a phoneme will (1) always pronounce that sound differently from other sounds. She will also (2) be aware of and be able to hear the difference between that sound and other sounds, and (3) use that difference to help her arrive at the meaning of the words that she hears. Linguists studying ongoing sound mergers, when two phonemes collapse into one, have found that individuals in the middle of a change sometimes do (1) but not (2) or (3). For example, they sometimes distinguish two sounds clearly in their speech and then then don't seem to be able to tell those sounds apart. These observations challenge our assumptions of what having a phoneme means. They highlight the need to study individuals in situations of language change and to carefully observe both their natural way of speaking, as sociolinguists do, and also their perception at different levels. The latter requires rigorous experimental methodology, which is found in psycholinguistics but has until recently rarely been applied to situations of variation and change.
In the Spanish city of Seville, as in other cities across the southern region of Andalusia, contact with the prestigious standard variety to the north is leading to the emergence of a new sound /θ/ in contexts where before there was only /s/. The change is unusual in that it involves the addition of a phoneme. This study joins a set of studies examining this change as it proceeds across the region. In doing so, it is novel in combining sociolinguistic and psycholinguistic approaches. 30-60 minute interviews were conducted with 24 young adult speakers from the city of Seville. Their speech was transcribed and time-aligned, and a total of 15,979 instances of the relevant sounds were analyzed. In addition, three perceptual experiments were designed and conducted with these same speakers as subjects.
The results show that the speakers (1) produce two different sounds, which can easily be perceived auditorily and roughly separated in acoustic space. However, many of them don't do exactly what speakers of the standard dialect do in their speech. Instead, they produce a mixture of [s] and the new sound [θ] in contexts where the standard has [θ], and they are variable within lexical items; they pronounce the same word two different ways. However, when their speech is examined individually, a systematic pattern is revealed: most of the speakers categorically limit [θ] to /θ/ contexts. That is; they don't pronounce just any word that used to have [s] with [θ], but rather they use [θ] in places where there is a /θ/ in the standard dialect. (An analogy in English is if a speaker pronounced three as both [θri] and [sri], but never said [θi] for see.) The speakers are also (2) easily able to hear the difference between [s] and [θ], as shown by the results of two experiments in which the subjects had to identify and discriminate the sounds from each other. All together, we take this evidence for these speakers having an underlying phonological contrast whose borrowing may have been made possible, as others have suggested, by the high level of social awareness it enjoys.
A third experiment examined (3), their use of the contrast in understanding words. The speakers listened to words that would have a /θ/ sound in the standard dialect. These words were recorded by a local who was asked to pronounce some of them with [s] and some with [θ]. This word was followed by another word which was sometimes related to the first word in meaning, and sometimes not. We measured how much faster the speakers reacted to that second word when it was a related word, and compared the size of that speedup (priming effect) depending on the pronunciation. The results suggest that the speakers processed words better when they were pronounced in the local way, with [s]. This result is surprising given that the speakers appear to have two sound categories, not one. However, we hypothesize that this seemingly incongruent result may be evidence for phonemic flexibility in perception. Because the person speaking the words sounded very local, the speakers expected him to have only one category, and adjusted their expectations accordingly. Future work can explicitly test this hypothesis.
This research underscores the complexity of the notion of phonemic contrast. It add to a small set of studies examining ongoing phoneme additions. In general, it highlights the potential benefits of combining naturalistic and experimental approaches to variable linguistic phenomena.
